title: 108_s1728
content: The Act is titled the "Terrorism Victim Compensation Equity Act" and references the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund of 2001. It provides compensation for victims of terrorist acts. The Terrorism Victim Compensation Equity Act expands eligibility for compensation to victims of terrorist acts, including the bombings of U.S. embassies in East Africa, the attack on the U.S.S. Cole, and the attack on the World Trade Center. The Terrorism Victim Compensation Equity Act expands eligibility for compensation to victims of terrorist acts, including the bombings of U.S. embassies in East Africa, the attack on the U.S.S. Cole, and the attack on the World Trade Center. The Act also extends the time limit for filing claims from 2 years to 3 years and includes provisions for collateral compensation. The Terrorism Victim Compensation Equity Act broadens eligibility for compensation to victims of terrorist acts, including the bombings of U.S. embassies in East Africa, the attack on the U.S.S. Cole, and the attack on the World Trade Center. It extends the time limit for filing claims from 2 years to 3 years and includes provisions for collateral compensation for individuals present at specific locations during the attacks. The Terrorism Victim Compensation Equity Act expands compensation eligibility for victims of terrorist acts, including air crashes and bombings. Claimants waive the right to file civil actions in federal or state courts for damages sustained. The Terrorism Victim Compensation Equity Act allows victims of terrorist acts to seek compensation for damages sustained in events like bombings and attacks on US embassies and ships. Claimants must waive the right to file civil actions for these damages. Individuals seeking compensation under this act must withdraw from any civil action within 90 days of regulations being promulgated. Those who have already received compensation from a civil action related to embassy bombings are not eligible for compensation under this subsection. The act specifies that individuals cannot receive compensation under this act if they have already received it from a civil action related to embassy bombings. Individuals are ineligible for compensation under this act if they were involved in the bombings of U.S. embassies in East Africa, the attack on the U.S.S. Cole, or the attack on the World Trade Center. An amendment to Section 405(c) states that members of the uniformed services cannot be excluded from eligibility for benefits under the act. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Special Master, must create regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment. These regulations will cover forms for submitting claims, required information, hearing procedures, assistance for claim filing, and other relevant matters.
